description: From Middle English cenyth, from Medieval Latin cenit, from Arabic سَمْت‎ (samt, “direction, path”), from the fuller form سَمْت اَلرَّأْس‎ (samt ar-raʔs, “direction of the head”). The -ni- for -m- is sometimes thought to be due to a misreading of the three strokes, which is plausible, though it could be a mere phonetic approximation.

entries.meaning: (astronomy) The point in the sky vertically above a given position or observer; the point in the celestial sphere opposite the nadir.
(astronomy) The highest point in the sky reached by a celestial body.
examples: As far to the west as Monica could see, her world was a sea of fog,  […] . Above it arched a cerulean sky; as the sun climbed to the zenith,  […] , the fog gradually took on a bluish tinge.

entries.meaning: (by extension) Highest point or state; peak.
examples: Winning the continental championship was the zenith of my career.
